docs.title: Mbodi Handbook
docs.text:
Welcome to the Mbodi Company Handbook! This is our central repository for company information, processes, and guidelines.

Mbodi AI is an allusion to the n-body problem and embodied intelligence representing a first-principled approach to achieving the latter.

docs.text:
• Company Overview - Learn about our mission, values, and objectives
  • Engineering - Technical documentation and processes
  • Product - Product requirements and specifications
  • Operations - Day-to-day operational procedures
  • People - HR policies and team information
  • Security - Security policies and procedures
  • Legal - Legal documents and compliance information

docs.title: About This Handbook
docs.text:
This handbook is designed to be:

  • Transparent - Open information about how we work
  • Living - Continuously updated as we grow and learn
  • Accessible - Easy to find what you need
  • Comprehensive - Covering all aspects of working at Mbodi

docs.title: Contributing
docs.text:
This handbook is maintained collaboratively. If you find information that's out of date or missing, please:

  1. Create an issue in the handbook repository
  2. Submit a pull request with your proposed changes
  3. Reach out to the team for clarification

docs.title: How We Communicate
docs.text: Effective communication is essential for our distributed, research-driven team. Our communication practices emphasize transparency, inclusivity, and efficient knowledge sharing.

docs.title: 🌐 Transparency by Default
docs.text:
• Share information openly unless there's a specific reason not to
  • Make decisions and reasoning visible to the entire team
  • Document important discussions and outcomes
  • Provide context for decisions and changes

docs.title: 📝 Written First
docs.text:
• Document important information in writing for future reference
  • Use asynchronous communication to respect different time zones and work styles
  • Create searchable records of decisions and discussions
  • Supplement verbal communication with written summaries

docs.title: 🎯 Purpose-Driven
docs.text:
• Be clear about the purpose and expected outcomes of communications
  • Choose the right medium for the message and audience
  • Respect people's time and attention
  • Follow up on action items and commitments

docs.title: 🤝 Inclusive & Respectful
docs.text:
• Ensure all team members can participate regardless of location or schedule
  • Use clear, jargon-free language when possible
  • Provide multiple ways for people to contribute and ask questions
  • Foster psychological safety for open dialogue

docs.title: Slack (Real-time Discussion)
docs.text:
#general - Company-wide announcements and discussions - Important company updates - All-hands meeting coordination - General questions and discussions

#research - Research team collaboration - Paper discussions and literature reviews - Research findings and breakthroughs - Academic collaboration opportunities

#engineering - Engineering team coordination - Technical discussions and problem-solving - Code reviews and architecture decisions - Infrastructure updates and alerts

#product - Product development and strategy - Customer feedback and requirements - Product roadmap discussions - Market research and competitive analysis

#random - Casual conversation and team building - Personal updates and celebrations - Interesting articles and resources - Team building activities and events

#alerts - System monitoring and notifications - Production system alerts - Deployment notifications - Security and compliance updates

docs.title: Email (Formal Communication)
docs.text:
• External communication with customers, partners, and vendors
  • Legal and compliance communications
  • Formal announcements and policy changes
  • Meeting invitations and calendar coordination

docs.title: GitHub (Technical Collaboration)
docs.text:
• Code reviews and technical discussions
  • Issue tracking and project management
  • Documentation and knowledge sharing
  • Open-source collaboration and contributions

docs.title: Notion (Documentation & Knowledge Base)
docs.text:
• Long-form documentation and processes
  • Meeting notes and decision records
  • Project planning and tracking
  • Knowledge base and FAQ

docs.title: Video Calls (Face-to-Face Interaction)
docs.text:
• Team meetings and standup calls
  • Customer interviews and demos
  • Brainstorming and collaborative sessions
  • One-on-one meetings and performance reviews

docs.title: Meeting Types
docs.text:
Standup Meetings (Daily, 15 minutes) - What did you accomplish yesterday? - What are you working on today? - Any blockers or help needed? - Keep it brief and focused on coordination

Sprint Planning (Weekly, 1 hour) - Review completed work and lessons learned - Plan upcoming work and priorities - Identify dependencies and resource needs - Align on goals and expectations

All-Hands (Monthly, 1 hour) - Company updates and strategic direction - Team highlights and achievements - Q&A with leadership - Recognition and celebrations

Research Reviews (Bi-weekly, 1 hour) - Present research findings and progress - Discuss technical challenges and solutions - Plan future research directions - Collaborate on publications and presentations

docs.title: Meeting Best Practices
docs.text:
Before the Meeting: - Create and share an agenda in advance - Include relevant background materials and context - Define clear objectives and expected outcomes - Invite only necessary participants

During the Meeting: - Start and end on time - Follow the agenda and stay focused - Encourage participation from all attendees - Take notes and document decisions - Assign clear action items with owners and deadlines

After the Meeting: - Share meeting notes and action items within 24 hours - Follow up on commitments and deadlines - Update relevant documentation and systems - Schedule follow-up meetings if needed

docs.title: Types of Documentation
docs.text:
Process Documentation - How to perform common tasks and procedures - Decision-making frameworks and approval processes - Onboarding and training materials - Emergency procedures and incident response

Technical Documentation - API documentation and integration guides - Architecture decisions and design documents - Code documentation and commenting standards - Deployment and operational procedures

Project Documentation - Project requirements and specifications - Progress updates and status reports - Lessons learned and post-mortems - Customer feedback and research findings

docs.title: Writing Guidelines
docs.text:
Structure: - Use clear headings and organization - Include a summary or overview section - Provide step-by-step instructions where appropriate - Link to related documents and resources

Style: - Write for your audience's knowledge level - Use active voice and clear, concise language - Include examples and visuals where helpful - Keep documents up-to-date and accurate

Accessibility: - Use descriptive link text and alt text for images - Organize content with proper heading hierarchy - Ensure documents are searchable and discoverable - Provide multiple formats when necessary

docs.title: Time Zone Considerations
docs.text:
• Schedule meetings during core overlap hours (10 AM - 2 PM PT)
  • Record important meetings for those who can't attend live
  • Use asynchronous communication for non-urgent matters
  • Respect local holidays and working hours

docs.title: Virtual Collaboration Tools
docs.text:
• Use shared documents for real-time collaboration
  • Leverage screen sharing for technical discussions
  • Create virtual whiteboard sessions for brainstorming
  • Maintain social connections through virtual coffee chats

docs.title: Presence and Availability
docs.text:
• Update your Slack status to indicate availability
  • Use calendar blocking for focused work time
  • Communicate your working hours and preferences
  • Be responsive within reasonable time frames

docs.title: Giving Feedback
docs.text:
• Be specific and actionable in your feedback
  • Focus on behaviors and outcomes, not personalities
  • Provide both positive recognition and constructive criticism
  • Choose the appropriate time and setting for feedback

docs.title: Receiving Feedback
docs.text:
• Listen actively and ask clarifying questions
  • Separate feedback from personal identity
  • Thank people for taking the time to provide feedback
  • Follow up on action items and improvements

docs.title: Continuous Improvement
docs.text:
• Regular team retrospectives to improve processes
  • Anonymous feedback channels for sensitive topics
  • Leadership office hours for open dialogue
  • Regular surveys to measure communication effectiveness

docs.title: Incident Response
docs.text:
• Use #alerts channel for immediate notifications
  • Follow escalation procedures for critical issues
  • Provide regular updates during ongoing incidents
  • Conduct post-incident reviews and documentation

docs.title: Crisis Communication
docs.text:
• Designated spokespeople for external communication
  • Clear internal communication chains and responsibilities
  • Regular updates to all stakeholders
  • Coordination with legal and PR as needed

Effective communication is a skill we continuously develop and improve. These guidelines help us work together efficiently while building strong relationships and maintaining our collaborative culture.

docs.title: How We Hire
docs.text: Our hiring process is designed to identify exceptional individuals who share our mission of advancing embodied intelligence and can thrive in our collaborative, research-driven environment.

docs.title: What We Look For
docs.text:
** Intellectual Curiosity** - Passion for understanding how things work at a fundamental level - Comfort with ambiguity and complex, unsolved problems - Continuous learning mindset and adaptability

** Scientific Rigor** - Strong foundation in relevant technical disciplines - Experience with experimental design and hypothesis testing - Commitment to reproducible, evidence-based work

** Collaborative Spirit** - Ability to work effectively in interdisciplinary teams - Strong communication skills across technical and non-technical audiences - Willingness to share knowledge and learn from others

** Impact Orientation** - Drive to solve real-world problems with meaningful applications - Balance of theoretical understanding and practical implementation - Entrepreneurial mindset and ownership mentality

docs.title: Diversity & Inclusion
docs.text: We believe diverse perspectives make us stronger. We actively seek candidates from: - Different academic and professional backgrounds - Underrepresented groups in AI and technology - Various geographic and cultural contexts - Different career stages and experience levels

docs.title: 1. Application Review
docs.text: Timeline: 1-2 weeks - Resume and portfolio evaluation - Assessment of alignment with role requirements - Initial screening for mission fit

docs.title: 2. Initial Screening
docs.text: Format: 30-minute video call Focus: - Career background and motivations - Interest in embodied AI and our mission - Basic technical competency for the role - Communication skills and cultural fit

docs.title: 3. Technical Assessment
docs.text: Format: Varies by role (see role-specific sections below) Focus: - Core technical skills relevant to the position - Problem-solving approach and methodology - Ability to explain complex concepts clearly

docs.title: 4. Team Interviews
docs.text: Format: 2-3 interviews with different team members Focus: - Deep technical discussion and collaboration - Values alignment and cultural fit - Working style and team dynamics - Questions about our company and role

docs.title: 5. Final Interview
docs.text: Format: Discussion with leadership team Focus: - Vision alignment and long-term goals - Leadership potential and growth trajectory - Final questions and role expectations

docs.title: 6. Reference Checks
docs.text:
• Verification of work history and performance
  • Insights into working style and collaboration
  • Confirmation of technical capabilities

docs.title: Research Scientists
docs.text:
Technical Assessment: Research presentation + Q&A - Present recent research work (30 minutes) - Deep technical discussion with research team - Whiteboard problem-solving session

Key Evaluation Criteria: - Research quality and impact - Technical depth in relevant areas - Ability to communicate complex ideas - Collaboration and mentorship potential

docs.title: Software Engineers
docs.text:
Technical Assessment: Coding interview + system design - Algorithm and data structure problems - System architecture discussion - Code review and debugging exercise

Key Evaluation Criteria: - Programming proficiency and best practices - System design and scalability thinking - Problem-solving approach - Code quality and maintainability

docs.title: Product Managers
docs.text:
Technical Assessment: Case study + strategy discussion - Product strategy case study - Technical requirements analysis - Customer scenario problem-solving

Key Evaluation Criteria: - Product strategy and vision - Technical understanding and communication - Customer empathy and market insight - Cross-functional collaboration skills

docs.title: Operations & Support
docs.text:
Technical Assessment: Role-specific scenarios - Process design and optimization - Problem-solving and troubleshooting - Communication and documentation skills

Key Evaluation Criteria: - Operational excellence mindset - Process improvement capabilities - Attention to detail and reliability - Customer service orientation

docs.title: For Candidates
docs.text:
Before the Interview: - Research our company, mission, and recent work - Review the job description and requirements - Prepare questions about the role and team - Practice explaining your background and motivations

During the Interview: - Be authentic and honest about your experience - Ask thoughtful questions about our work and culture - Demonstrate your problem-solving process - Show enthusiasm for embodied AI and our mission

After the Interview: - Send thank-you notes to your interviewers - Provide any additional information requested - Follow up on timeline and next steps

docs.title: For Interviewers
docs.text:
Preparation: - Review candidate's resume and application materials - Prepare role-specific questions and scenarios - Coordinate with other interviewers to avoid overlap - Set up technical requirements (whiteboard, laptop, etc.)

During the Interview: - Create a welcoming, inclusive environment - Focus on competencies relevant to the role - Give candidates time to ask questions - Take detailed notes for decision-making

Evaluation: - Assess candidates against our hiring criteria - Provide specific, actionable feedback - Collaborate with team on final decisions - Maintain confidentiality throughout the process

docs.title: Evaluation Criteria
docs.text:
• Technical Competence (40%): Skills and knowledge relevant to the role
  • Cultural Fit (30%): Alignment with values and working style
  • Growth Potential (20%): Ability to learn and take on new challenges
  • Mission Alignment (10%): Passion for embodied AI and our goals

docs.title: Decision Process
docs.text:
1. All interviewers submit written feedback
  2. Hiring team discusses candidate strengths and concerns
  3. Consensus-building on hire/no-hire decision
  4. Final approval from hiring manager and leadership
  5. Feedback provided to candidate within 48 hours

docs.title: First Week
docs.text:
• Company orientation and mission deep-dive
  • Team introductions and role expectations
  • Technical setup and tool access
  • Initial project assignments

docs.title: First Month
docs.text:
• Regular check-ins with manager and buddy
  • Technical training and skill development
  • Project ramp-up and team integration
  • Feedback and adjustment discussions

docs.title: First Quarter
docs.text:
• Performance review and goal setting
  • Expanded project responsibilities
  • Professional development planning
  • Full team integration and contribution

docs.title: Continuous Improvement
docs.text:
We regularly review and improve our hiring process based on: - Candidate feedback and experience surveys - Hiring outcome analysis and performance correlation - Industry best practices and research - Diversity and inclusion metrics

Our goal is to create a hiring experience that is fair, efficient, and representative of our company culture while identifying the best possible candidates for our team.

Our hiring process reflects our values of scientific rigor, collaboration, and continuous improvement. We're committed to building a diverse, exceptional team that can advance the field of embodied AI.

docs.title: Our Founding Story
docs.text:
Mbodi AI was born from a fundamental question: How can artificial intelligence truly understand and interact with the physical world?

The founding team, with backgrounds in robotics, physics, and AI research, recognized that current AI systems excel at pattern recognition and language processing but struggle with the intuitive understanding of physical interactions that comes naturally to biological intelligence. The company name itself—an allusion to the n-body problem in physics—reflects our commitment to tackling complex, multi-agent interactions in dynamic environments.

docs.title: Mission Statement
docs.text:
Mbodi AI is dedicated to advancing embodied intelligence through a first-principled approach to solving the n-body problem in artificial intelligence.

We believe that true artificial intelligence must be grounded in physical understanding and embodied interaction with the world. Our mission is to create AI systems that can perceive, reason, and act in complex, dynamic environments with the same intuitive understanding that comes naturally to biological intelligence.

docs.title: Vision
docs.text: To create AI systems that seamlessly integrate into the physical world, understanding not just what to do, but how and why to do it, leading to more capable, reliable, and intuitive artificial intelligence.

docs.title: Embodied Intelligence
docs.text: We focus on AI that understands the physical world through embodied experience, not just abstract reasoning. Our systems learn through interaction, developing intuitive physics and spatial reasoning capabilities.

docs.title: First-Principles Approach
docs.text: We build from fundamental principles rather than relying solely on pattern matching or statistical correlations. This approach ensures our AI systems have robust, generalizable understanding.

docs.title: N-Body Problem Inspiration
docs.text: Just as the n-body problem in physics deals with predicting the motion of multiple interacting objects, we tackle the challenge of AI systems that must understand and navigate complex, multi-agent environments.

docs.title: Primary Customer Personas
docs.text:
Robotics Companies - Building autonomous systems that need to interact with dynamic environments - Require AI that understands physics and spatial relationships - Need reliable, predictable AI behavior in real-world scenarios

Industrial Automation - Manufacturing and logistics companies seeking intelligent automation - Need AI that can adapt to changing physical conditions - Require safety-critical AI systems with explainable behavior

Research Institutions - Academic and corporate research labs advancing AI capabilities - Need cutting-edge tools for embodied AI research - Require reproducible, scientifically rigorous AI systems

Simulation & Gaming - Companies building realistic virtual worlds and training environments - Need AI agents that behave naturally in simulated physics - Require scalable solutions for multi-agent scenarios

docs.title: Unique Differentiators
docs.text:
Physics-First AI - Unlike purely data-driven approaches, we build AI that understands fundamental physical principles - Our systems can generalize to new situations by reasoning from first principles

Scientific Rigor - We apply the scientific method to AI development with reproducible experiments - All our work is grounded in peer-reviewed research and open science principles

Real-World Focus - While others focus on virtual environments, we prioritize real-world deployment - Our AI systems are designed to handle the complexity and unpredictability of physical reality

Collaborative Approach - We believe in open science and actively contribute to the research community - Our solutions are designed to integrate with existing systems and workflows

docs.title: Impact Goals
docs.text:
• Scientific Advancement - Push the boundaries of AI research and embodied intelligence
  • Practical Applications - Develop AI that solves real-world problems across industries
  • Ethical Development - Ensure our AI systems are safe, beneficial, and aligned with human values
  • Knowledge Sharing - Contribute to the broader AI research community through open science

This mission and vision guide all our decisions and serve as the foundation for our company values and objectives.

docs.title: What are OKRs?
docs.text:
Objectives and Key Results (OKRs) are our goal-setting framework that helps us:

  • Align on priorities across the company
  • Set ambitious but achievable goals
  • Track progress transparently
  • Focus on outcomes, not just activities

docs.title: Structure
docs.text:
• Objectives - Qualitative, inspirational descriptions of what we want to achieve
  • Key Results - Quantitative, measurable outcomes that indicate success

docs.title: Company-Wide Objectives
docs.text: OKRs will be populated here at the beginning of each quarter

docs.title: Quarterly Cycle
docs.text:
1. Planning (Month 3 of previous quarter)
  2. Leadership sets company-level objectives
  3. Teams propose supporting objectives and key results

  4. Review and alignment sessions

  5. Execution (Months 1-3 of current quarter)

  6. Weekly check-ins on progress
  7. Mid-quarter reviews and adjustments

  8. Continuous tracking and updates

  9. Review (End of quarter)

  10. Score key results (0.0 - 1.0 scale)
  11. Reflect on learnings and insights
  12. Plan improvements for next cycle

docs.title: Scoring Guidelines
docs.text:
• 0.7 - 1.0 - Excellent performance
  • 0.4 - 0.6 - Good progress with room for improvement
  • 0.0 - 0.3 - Needs attention and course correction

We aim for an average score of 0.6-0.7. If we're consistently scoring 1.0, our goals may not be ambitious enough.

docs.title: Writing Good Objectives
docs.text:
• Inspirational - Motivate the team
  • Qualitative - Describe what good looks like
  • Time-bound - Clear timeframe (usually quarterly)
  • Actionable - Team can influence the outcome

docs.title: Writing Good Key Results
docs.text:
• Measurable - Clear metrics and numbers
  • Achievable - Stretch goals but not impossible
  • Specific - No ambiguity about what success means
  • Outcome-focused - Results, not activities

docs.title: Example OKR
docs.text:
Objective: Advance the state of embodied AI research

Key Results: - Publish 2 peer-reviewed papers in top-tier AI conferences - Achieve 15% improvement in benchmark performance on embodied reasoning tasks - Open-source 1 significant research contribution with >100 GitHub stars

docs.title: Team OKRs
docs.text:
Each team develops supporting OKRs that ladder up to company objectives:

  • Engineering - Technical capabilities and platform development
  • Research - Scientific breakthroughs and publications
  • Product - User experience and market validation
  • Operations - Efficiency and scalability improvements

docs.title: Historical OKRs
docs.text: We maintain a record of past OKRs to track our evolution and learn from our goal-setting patterns.

docs.title: Archive
docs.text:
Historical OKRs will be archived here for reference and learning

OKRs are reviewed and updated quarterly. For questions about the OKR process, reach out to the leadership team.

docs.title: Organization Structure
docs.text: Our organizational structure is designed to support rapid innovation while maintaining scientific rigor and collaborative decision-making.

docs.title: Flat & Flexible
docs.text:
• Minimal hierarchical layers to reduce communication overhead
  • Cross-functional teams organized around projects and outcomes
  • Decision-making authority distributed to those closest to the work

docs.title: Mission-Driven Teams
docs.text:
• Teams organized around customer problems and scientific challenges
  • Clear ownership and accountability for outcomes
  • Autonomy to make decisions within defined boundaries

docs.title: Scientific Collaboration
docs.text:
• Open sharing of research and findings across teams
  • Regular cross-team collaboration and knowledge exchange
  • Peer review and scientific rigor in all technical decisions

Our organizational structure is designed to evolve with our growth while preserving the collaborative, mission-driven culture that makes us successful.

docs.title: Product Principles
docs.text: Our product principles guide how we design, build, and deliver AI solutions. These principles ensure consistency across all our products and align with our mission of advancing embodied intelligence.

docs.title: Physics-First Design
docs.text:
Principle: Every product feature should be grounded in physical understanding and real-world applicability.

What this means: - We prioritize solutions that work in physical environments over purely virtual ones - Our AI models incorporate physics constraints and principles from the ground up - Features are validated against real-world scenarios, not just synthetic benchmarks

Examples: - Motion planning that respects momentum and inertia - Object interaction models based on material properties - Sensor fusion that accounts for physical sensor limitations

docs.title: Scientific Transparency
docs.text:
Principle: Our products should be explainable, reproducible, and scientifically rigorous.

What this means: - All AI decisions can be traced back to underlying principles or data - Our methods are documented and reproducible by others - We provide uncertainty estimates and confidence intervals

Examples: - Clear documentation of model architectures and training procedures - Uncertainty quantification in all predictions - Open-source components where possible

docs.title: Progressive Capability
docs.text:
Principle: Products should demonstrate continuous improvement and learning capabilities.

What this means: - Systems can adapt and improve through experience - New capabilities build upon existing foundations - Performance degrades gracefully when encountering novel situations

Examples: - Online learning from deployment experiences - Modular architectures that support capability expansion - Fallback behaviors for out-of-distribution scenarios

docs.title: Safety-Critical Reliability
docs.text:
Principle: All products must operate safely in real-world environments with human interaction.

What this means: - Safety is designed in from the beginning, not added later - Systems have multiple layers of safety checks and fallbacks - Failure modes are predictable and recoverable

Examples: - Formal verification of critical system components - Redundant safety systems and graceful degradation - Comprehensive testing in simulation before real-world deployment

docs.title: Human-AI Collaboration
docs.text:
Principle: Products should augment human capabilities rather than replace human judgment.

What this means: - Humans remain in control of critical decisions - AI provides insights and recommendations, not mandates - Interfaces are intuitive and support human understanding

Examples: - Explainable AI that shows reasoning processes - Human-in-the-loop validation for critical decisions - Intuitive visualization of AI system state and confidence

docs.title: Feature Development Process
docs.text:
1. Physics Validation - Ensure new features respect physical constraints
  2. Scientific Review - Peer review of technical approaches and assumptions
  3. Safety Analysis - Comprehensive safety and failure mode analysis
  4. Human Factors - User experience and human-AI interaction design
  5. Real-World Testing - Validation in actual deployment environments

docs.title: Quality Standards
docs.text:
• Accuracy: Performance meets or exceeds established benchmarks
  • Reliability: Consistent performance across varied conditions
  • Explainability: Clear reasoning for all system decisions
  • Safety: Formal safety guarantees where applicable
  • Usability: Intuitive interfaces for human operators

docs.title: Success Metrics
docs.text:
• Technical Performance: Benchmark scores and real-world effectiveness
  • User Adoption: Customer satisfaction and system utilization
  • Scientific Impact: Publications and community contributions
  • Safety Record: Incident rates and safety performance
  • Business Value: Customer outcomes and return on investment

docs.title: Continuous Improvement
docs.text:
Our product principles evolve based on: - Customer feedback and use cases - Scientific advances in embodied AI - Real-world deployment experiences - Industry best practices and standards

We review and update these principles quarterly to ensure they continue to serve our mission and customers effectively.

These principles are living guidelines that shape every product decision we make. They ensure our solutions remain true to our mission while delivering real value to our customers.

docs.title: Tools We Use
docs.text: This section documents the core tools and platforms that power our daily work at Mbodi. Understanding our tool stack helps new team members get productive quickly and ensures everyone is using our systems effectively.

docs.title: Notion
docs.text:
Purpose: Central documentation, project planning, and knowledge base Access: All team members with workspace access Use Cases: Meeting notes, project documentation, process guides, team wiki, project planning

Best Practices: - Use consistent templates for meeting notes and project documentation - Link related pages and maintain clear page hierarchies - Keep information current and archive outdated content - Use @mentions for collaboration and task assignments - Organize content with clear naming conventions and tags

docs.title: Google Drive
docs.text:
Purpose: File storage, document collaboration, and sharing Access: All team members with company Google accounts Use Cases: Document collaboration, file sharing, presentation storage, form creation

Best Practices: - Use shared drives for team collaboration - Maintain consistent folder structures and naming conventions - Set appropriate sharing permissions and access levels - Use version history and commenting for collaborative editing - Regularly clean up and organize files

docs.title: GitHub
docs.text:
Purpose: Code repository, version control, and development collaboration Access: All technical team members with organization access Use Cases: Source code management, code reviews, issue tracking, documentation, CI/CD workflows

Best Practices: - Write clear, descriptive commit messages following conventional commit format - Use pull requests for all code changes with required reviews - Follow consistent branch naming: feature/description, bugfix/description, hotfix/description - Keep repositories organized with clear README files and documentation - Use GitHub Issues for bug tracking and feature requests - Implement branch protection rules for main/production branches - Tag releases and maintain changelog documentation

docs.title: GitHub ↔ Linear Integration
docs.text:
Purpose: Seamless connection between code changes and project management Setup: Automatic linking of commits, PRs, and issues using Linear's GitHub app

Workflow: - Reference Linear issues in commit messages: git commit -m "feat: add user auth (LIN-123)" - Pull requests automatically update linked Linear issues - Issue status changes based on PR status (merged = completed) - Use Linear's branch creation feature to maintain consistent naming

docs.title: Notion ↔ Other Tools
docs.text: Purpose: Central documentation hub that references work across platforms Integration Points: - Embed Linear roadmaps and project views in Notion pages - Link to GitHub repositories and documentation from Notion - Store Google Drive files and folders within Notion pages - Create meeting notes that reference Linear issues and GitHub discussions

docs.title: Linear
docs.text:
Purpose: Issue tracking, project management, and development workflow Access: All team members with workspace access Use Cases: Bug tracking, feature requests, sprint planning, roadmap management, task assignment

Best Practices: - Write clear, actionable issue descriptions with acceptance criteria - Use consistent labeling system: bug, feature, improvement, documentation - Set appropriate priorities: urgent, high, medium, low - Link related issues and GitHub pull requests - Update issue status regularly and add progress comments - Use Linear's GitHub integration to automatically update issues from commits - Organize work into projects and milestones for better tracking - Use estimates and cycle tracking for sprint planning

docs.text:

docs.text:
1. Google Workspace: Create company email and Google Drive access
  2. GitHub: Add to Mbodi organization with appropriate team membership
  3. Linear: Invite to workspace with member-level access

docs.text:
1. Submit Request: Use Linear issue template for access requests
  2. Manager Approval: Direct manager approves the request

docs.text:

  • [ ] Remove from Linear workspace
  • [ ] Transfer ownership of Notion pages and databases
  • [ ] Remove from Google Drive shared drives
  • [ ] Transfer or archive important work documents

docs.title: Daily Workflow
docs.text:
1. Start with Linear: Check assigned issues and daily priorities
  2. GitHub: Create feature branches using Linear's branch creation
  3. Development: Make commits with Linear issue references
  4. Documentation: Update relevant Notion pages with progress
  5. Collaboration: Share files via Google Drive, discuss in Linear comments

docs.title: Communication Guidelines
docs.text:
• Quick Updates: Use Linear comments for project-specific updates
  • Documentation: Use Notion for detailed documentation and meeting notes
  • File Sharing: Use Google Drive for documents, presentations, and large files
  • Code Discussion: Use GitHub PR comments for technical discussions

docs.title: Organization Standards
docs.text:
• Naming Conventions: Use consistent naming across all platforms
  • Tagging: Apply consistent labels in Linear and tags in Notion
  • File Structure: Maintain organized folder structures in Drive and Notion
  • Version Control: Use semantic versioning and clear commit messages

docs.title: Regular Maintenance Tasks
docs.text:
• Weekly: Clean up completed Linear issues and outdated Notion pages
  • Monthly: Review and organize Google Drive folders and permissions
  • Quarterly: Audit access permissions across all platforms
  • Annually: Evaluate tool effectiveness and consider alternatives

docs.title: Troubleshooting & Support
docs.text:
• GitHub Issues: Check GitHub Status page, contact GitHub Support
  • Linear Problems: Use Linear's in-app support or community forum
  • Notion Outages: Check Notion Status page, use mobile app as backup
  • Google Drive: Google Workspace Admin console, Google Support

This documentation reflects our core tool stack: GitHub, Linear, Notion, and Google Drive. As we grow and our needs evolve, we'll evaluate additional tools that integrate well with this foundation.

docs.title: Core Values
docs.text: Our values define how we work, make decisions, and interact with each other and the world. They are the foundation of our culture and guide everything we do at Mbodi.

docs.title: Scientific Rigor
docs.text:
We approach problems with intellectual honesty and methodological precision.

  • Evidence-based decisions - We rely on data, experimentation, and peer review
  • Reproducible research - Our work can be validated and built upon by others
  • Continuous learning - We update our understanding as we gain new insights
  • Intellectual humility - We acknowledge what we don't know and learn from mistakes

docs.title: Collaborative Excellence
docs.text:
We believe the best solutions emerge from diverse perspectives working together.

  • Open communication - We share ideas, feedback, and knowledge freely
  • Inclusive environment - We value different backgrounds, experiences, and viewpoints
  • Team success - We prioritize collective achievement over individual recognition
  • Constructive feedback - We give and receive feedback to help everyone grow

docs.title: Purpose-Driven Innovation
docs.text:
We innovate with intention, always considering the broader impact of our work.

  • Meaningful problems - We focus on challenges that matter to humanity
  • Ethical considerations - We consider the implications of our technology
  • Long-term thinking - We build for sustainable, lasting impact
  • Responsible development - We develop AI that is safe and beneficial

docs.title: Adaptive Resilience
docs.text:
We embrace change and learn from both successes and failures.

  • Growth mindset - We see challenges as opportunities to improve
  • Iterative improvement - We continuously refine our approaches
  • Failure tolerance - We learn from setbacks without fear of blame
  • Agile response - We adapt quickly to new information and circumstances

docs.title: Excellence in Execution
docs.text:
We strive for the highest quality in everything we do.

  • Attention to detail - We care about getting the small things right
  • Craft mastery - We continuously develop our skills and expertise
  • Reliable delivery - We meet our commitments and deadlines
  • Quality standards - We maintain high standards for our work and outputs

docs.title: Living Our Values
docs.text:
These values are not just words on a page – they guide our daily actions:

  • In hiring - We look for people who embody these values
  • In performance reviews - We evaluate both what people accomplish and how they do it
  • In decision making - We use these values as a framework for tough choices
  • In conflict resolution - We return to these shared principles when disagreements arise

docs.title: Value in Action
docs.text:
Examples of how our values show up in practice:

  • Sharing research findings openly with the scientific community
  • Taking time to mentor junior team members
  • Choosing projects based on potential positive impact, not just technical challenge
  • Admitting when we're wrong and changing course based on new evidence
  • Celebrating team achievements and learning from failures together

These values evolve with us. We regularly reflect on and refine them to ensure they continue to serve our mission and culture.

docs.title: Engineering
docs.text:

docs.title: Engineering Principles
docs.text: Our engineering practices are guided by these core principles:

docs.title: 🏗️ Build for Scale
docs.text:
• Modular Architecture - Design systems that can grow and evolve

  • Fault Tolerance - Build systems that gracefully handle failures
  • Horizontal Scaling - Design for distributed, scalable architectures

docs.title: 🔬 Research-Driven Development
docs.text:
• Scientific Method - Apply rigorous experimentation to engineering decisions
  • Reproducible Results - Ensure our systems and experiments can be replicated
  • Evidence-Based Choices - Use data and benchmarks to guide technical decisions
  • Open Source Contribution - Share our learnings with the broader community

docs.title: 🛡️ Security & Reliability
docs.text:

  • Comprehensive Testing - Unit, integration, and end-to-end testing strategies

docs.title: 🚀 Developer Experience

docs.title: Architecture Decision Records (ADRs)
docs.text: Architecture Decision Records (ADRs) document important architectural decisions made during the development of our systems.

docs.title: What are ADRs?
docs.text:
ADRs are short documents that capture:

  • Context - The situation that led to the decision
  • Decision - What was decided
  • Status - Proposed, accepted, deprecated, superseded
  • Consequences - Expected outcomes, both positive and negative

docs.title: Why We Use ADRs
docs.text:
• Historical Record - Understand why decisions were made
  • Knowledge Transfer - Help new team members understand the system
  • Decision Quality - Force us to think through implications
  • Accountability - Clear ownership of architectural choices

docs.title: ADR Template
docs.text:
# ADR-XXXX: [Title]

## Status

[Proposed | Accepted | Deprecated | Superseded by ADR-YYYY]

## Context

[Describe the situation that led to this decision]

## Decision

[Describe the decision that was made]

## Consequences

### Positive
- [List expected benefits]

### Negative
- [List expected drawbacks or risks]

### Neutral
- [List other implications]

docs.title: Active ADRs
docs.text: ADRs will be listed here as they are created

docs.title: Creating an ADR
docs.text:
1. Identify the Decision - Recognize when an architectural decision needs documentation
  2. Draft the ADR - Use the template above
  3. Review & Discussion - Share with the engineering team for feedback
  4. Finalize - Update status to "Accepted" once the decision is made
  5. Index - Add to this page for discoverability

docs.title: Updating ADRs
docs.text:
• ADRs should not be changed once accepted
  • If a decision changes, create a new ADR that supersedes the old one
  • Mark the old ADR as "Superseded by ADR-XXXX"

docs.title: ADR Numbering
docs.text:
• Use sequential numbering: ADR-0001, ADR-0002, etc.
  • Include the number in the filename: adr-0001-example-decision.md

docs.title: Categories
docs.text:
ADRs typically fall into these categories:

  • System Architecture - Overall system design decisions
  • Technology Choices - Programming languages, frameworks, tools
  • Data Architecture - Database design, data flow, storage decisions
  • Security Architecture - Authentication, authorization, encryption
  • Infrastructure - Deployment, scaling, monitoring decisions
  • API Design - Interface contracts and protocols

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
• Write for the Future - Assume readers don't have current context
  • Be Specific - Avoid vague language and provide concrete details
  • Include Alternatives - Mention options that were considered but rejected
  • Keep It Concise - ADRs should be readable in 5-10 minutes
  • Link to Resources - Reference relevant documentation, RFCs, or external sources

This section will grow as we make and document architectural decisions. All engineers are encouraged to contribute ADRs for significant decisions.

docs.title: RFCs (Request for Comments)
docs.text: Request for Comments (RFCs) are technical proposals that describe new features, processes, or significant changes to our systems.

docs.title: What are RFCs?
docs.text:
RFCs are detailed design documents that:

  • Propose Solutions - Describe how to solve a specific problem
  • Gather Feedback - Allow the team to review and improve proposals
  • Build Consensus - Help align the team on technical direction
  • Document Design - Serve as reference during implementation

docs.title: When to Write an RFC
docs.text:
Consider writing an RFC when:

  • Proposing a new system or major component
  • Making significant changes to existing systems
  • Introducing new technologies or frameworks
  • Establishing new processes or conventions
  • Making decisions that affect multiple teams

docs.title: RFC Template
docs.text:
# RFC-XXXX: [Title]

## Summary

[Brief description of the proposal]

## Motivation

[Why is this change needed? What problem does it solve?]

## Detailed Design

[Comprehensive description of the proposed solution]

### Architecture

[System architecture and component interactions]

### Implementation Plan

[How will this be implemented? What are the phases?]

### API/Interface Changes

[What APIs or interfaces will change?]

## Alternatives Considered

[What other approaches were considered and why were they rejected?]

## Risks and Mitigation

[What could go wrong? How will we address potential issues?]

## Testing Strategy

[How will we test this? What are the success criteria?]

## Migration Strategy

[How will we transition from the current state?]

## Timeline

[What are the key milestones and deadlines?]

## Open Questions

[What questions remain to be resolved?]

docs.title: Active RFCs
docs.text: RFCs will be listed here as they are created

docs.title: Lifecycle
docs.text:
1. Draft - Author creates initial RFC
  2. Review - Team provides feedback and suggestions
  3. Revision - Author incorporates feedback
  4. Approval - RFC is accepted for implementation
  5. Implementation - Development work begins
  6. Completion - RFC is marked as implemented

docs.title: Creating an RFC
docs.text:
1. Start with the Problem - Clearly define what you're trying to solve
  2. Research Existing Solutions - Look at how others have solved similar problems
  3. Draft the RFC - Use the template above
  4. Share Early - Get informal feedback before formal review
  5. Submit for Review - Post in engineering channels for team review
  6. Iterate - Incorporate feedback and refine the proposal
  7. Seek Approval - Get sign-off from relevant stakeholders

docs.title: Review Guidelines
docs.text:
When reviewing RFCs, consider:

  • Problem Clarity - Is the problem well-defined?
  • Solution Completeness - Does the proposal address all aspects?
  • Technical Soundness - Is the approach technically viable?
  • Alternatives - Were other options adequately considered?
  • Risks - Are potential issues identified and addressed?
  • Implementation - Is the plan realistic and achievable?

docs.title: RFC Categories
docs.text:
• Architecture - System design and structure
  • Features - New product capabilities
  • Infrastructure - Platform and tooling improvements
  • Process - Development and operational procedures
  • Research - Experimental approaches and investigations

docs.title: Writing Effective RFCs
docs.text:
• Start with Why - Clearly articulate the problem and motivation
  • Be Specific - Provide concrete examples and details
  • Consider Edge Cases - Think through unusual or error scenarios
  • Plan for Scale - Consider how the solution will handle growth
  • Include Diagrams - Visual representations help clarify complex ideas
  • Reference Standards - Link to relevant specifications and best practices

docs.title: Review Best Practices
docs.text:
• Ask Questions - Seek clarification on unclear points
  • Suggest Improvements - Offer constructive alternatives
  • Consider Implications - Think about broader system impacts
  • Be Respectful - Provide feedback that's helpful and kind
  • Focus on Technical Merit - Evaluate based on technical criteria

docs.title: Templates and Examples
docs.text:
RFC templates will be added here as needed for specific types of proposals.

RFCs are a collaborative process. Everyone is encouraged to participate in writing and reviewing RFCs to help shape our technical direction.

docs.title: Runbooks
docs.text: Runbooks are operational procedures that provide step-by-step instructions for common tasks, troubleshooting, and incident response.

docs.title: What are Runbooks?
docs.text:
Runbooks contain:

  • Standard Procedures - Step-by-step instructions for routine tasks
  • Troubleshooting Guides - How to diagnose and fix common issues
  • Incident Response - Procedures for handling emergencies
  • Maintenance Tasks - Regular operational activities

docs.title: Why We Use Runbooks
docs.text:
• Consistency - Ensure tasks are performed the same way every time
  • Knowledge Sharing - Capture tribal knowledge in accessible format
  • Faster Response - Reduce time to resolution during incidents
  • Training - Help new team members learn operational procedures
  • Reliability - Reduce human error through clear instructions

docs.title: System Operations
docs.text:
• Deployment procedures
  • Database maintenance
  • Backup and recovery
  • Performance monitoring
  • Scaling operations

docs.title: Incident Response
docs.text:
• Service outages
  • Performance degradation
  • Security incidents
  • Data corruption
  • Network issues

docs.title: Development Operations
docs.text:
• Environment setup
  • CI/CD troubleshooting
  • Code deployment
  • Testing procedures
  • Release management

docs.title: Monitoring & Alerting
docs.text:
• Alert response procedures
  • Log analysis
  • Metric interpretation
  • Dashboard maintenance
  • Notification management

docs.title: Runbook Template
docs.text:

docs.title: Development
docs.text:
• Development Environment Setup - Complete setup guide for new developers

Additional runbooks will be added here as operational procedures are documented.

docs.title: When to Create a Runbook
docs.text:
• Recurring Tasks - Procedures performed regularly
  • Complex Processes - Multi-step operations with dependencies
  • Critical Procedures - Tasks that must be done correctly
  • Knowledge Transfer - Documenting expert knowledge
  • Incident Response - Emergency procedures

docs.title: Writing Guidelines
docs.text:
• Be Specific - Include exact commands and parameters
  • Test Instructions - Verify procedures work as documented
  • Include Screenshots - Visual aids for complex UIs
  • Explain Why - Context helps with troubleshooting
  • Keep Updated - Review and update regularly
  • Use Clear Language - Write for someone unfamiliar with the task

docs.title: Review Process
docs.text:
1. Technical Review - Verify accuracy of procedures
  2. Usability Testing - Have someone else follow the runbook
  3. Stakeholder Approval - Get sign-off from relevant teams
  4. Regular Updates - Schedule periodic reviews

docs.title: Writing Effective Runbooks
docs.text:
• Start with the End Goal - Clearly state what success looks like
  • Assume No Prior Knowledge - Write for the least experienced user
  • Include Error Handling - What to do when things go wrong
  • Provide Context - Explain why steps are necessary
  • Use Consistent Formatting - Follow the template structure
  • Include Verification Steps - How to confirm each step worked

docs.title: Maintaining Runbooks
docs.text:
• Version Control - Track changes over time
  • Regular Reviews - Schedule quarterly reviews
  • Update After Incidents - Improve procedures based on real experiences
  • Gather Feedback - Ask users for improvement suggestions
  • Remove Obsolete Content - Archive outdated procedures

For urgent issues that can't be resolved using runbooks:

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Complete setup guide for new developers joining the Mbodi engineering team. This reflects our actual development stack and tooling.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• [ ] MacBook (Apple Silicon recommended) or Linux workstation
  • [ ] Admin access to install software
  • [ ] GitHub account with Mbodi organization access
  • [ ] Linear workspace invitation
  • [ ] Notion workspace invitation
  • [ ] Google Workspace account

docs.title: 1. Shell Configuration
docs.text:
Our team uses a standardized zsh configuration with custom tooling:

# Create local bin directory
mkdir -p ~/.local/bin

# Set up custom environment scripts
# (These will be provided during onboarding)
# ~/.local/bin/env - PATH management
# ~/.r.sh - Development tools setup (brew, pipx, uv, etc.)
# ~/.env.sh - Terminal colors and environment variables

# Add to ~/.zshrc (or create new file)
cat >> ~/.zshrc << 'EOF'
. "$HOME/.local/bin/env"
source ~/.r.sh
source ~/.env.sh

# Key bindings for word navigation
bindkey -e
bindkey $'\e[1;3D' backward-word
bindkey $'\e[1;3C' forward-word
bindkey $'\e[1;9D' backward-word
bindkey $'\e[1;9C' forward-word

# History configuration
HISTFILE=~/.zsh_history
HISTSIZE=100000
SAVEHIST=100000
setopt APPEND_HISTORY
setopt INC_APPEND_HISTORY
setopt SHARE_HISTORY
EOF

docs.title: 2. Python Environment Management
docs.text:
We use Conda for Python environment management:

# Install Miniconda (done automatically by r.sh)
# Initialize conda for zsh
conda init zsh

# Restart shell or source ~/.zshrc
source ~/.zshrc

docs.title: 3. Code Editors
docs.text:
Primary editor is Cursor, with additional tools available:

# Cursor (primary editor) - install manually from https://cursor.sh
# The r.sh script will set EDITOR=cursor automatically

# Windsurf (AI-powered editor) - optional
# Download from https://codeium.com/windsurf

docs.title: 4. Essential Development Tools
docs.text:
These are automatically installed by the r.sh script:

# Core tools (installed automatically):
# - Homebrew (package manager)
# - pipx (Python app installer) 
# - uv (fast Python package manager)
# - bat (better cat)
# - gh (GitHub CLI)

# Manual verification after setup:
which brew pipx uv bat gh

docs.title: 1. Clone Core Repositories
docs.text:
# Create project directory structure
mkdir -p ~/corp/projects && cd ~/corp/projects

# Clone the main mb project (contains tooling and utilities)
git clone git@github.com:mbodi/mb.git

# Clone other project repositories as needed
# git clone git@github.com:mbodi/[project-name].git

docs.title: 2. MB Tool Setup
docs.text:
Our custom mb tool provides project management and development utilities:

# Navigate to mb project
cd ~/corp/projects/mb

# Create and activate conda environment
conda create -n mb python=3.11
conda activate mb

# Install mb tool in development mode
pip install -e .

# Set up shell completions
mkdir -p ~/.config/zsh/completions
# Completion file should be provided during onboarding

# Add completion to ~/.zshrc (if not already present)
echo 'source ~/.config/zsh/completions/mb.zsh' >> ~/.zshrc

docs.title: 3. Project Environment Configuration
docs.text:
# Each project may have its own conda environment
# Example for a new project:
conda create -n project-name python=3.11
conda activate project-name

# Install project-specific dependencies
pip install -r requirements.txt
# or
pip install -e .

docs.title: 1. Environment Activation
docs.text:
# Start your day by activating the appropriate conda environment
conda activate mb  # for mb tool work
# or
conda activate project-name  # for specific project work

# Verify tools are available
which mb
mb --help  # should show available commands

docs.title: 2. Using the MB Tool
docs.text:
Our custom mb tool streamlines common development tasks:

# Common mb commands (examples - actual commands depend on implementation)
mb status          # Check project status
mb sync           # Sync with remote repositories  
mb test           # Run project tests
mb deploy         # Deploy to staging/production
mb env            # Environment management

# Use tab completion to discover available commands
mb <TAB><TAB>

docs.title: 3. Project-Specific Setup
docs.text:
Each project may have its own setup requirements:

# Navigate to project directory
cd ~/corp/projects/[project-name]

# Activate project environment
conda activate [project-name]

# Install/update dependencies
pip install -r requirements.txt
# or for development installs
pip install -e .

# Run project-specific setup
# (commands vary by project)

docs.title: 1. Linear + GitHub Integration
docs.text:
Our workflow integrates Linear issues with GitHub:

# Create feature branch from Linear issue
# (Linear can auto-create branches with proper naming)
git checkout -b feature/LIN-123-implement-user-auth

# Make commits referencing Linear issue
git commit -m "feat: implement user authentication (LIN-123)"

# Push and create PR
git push origin feature/LIN-123-implement-user-auth
# GitHub PR will automatically update the Linear issue

docs.title: 2. Using MB Tool for Git Operations
docs.text:
# Use mb tool for enhanced git operations
mb branch create LIN-123    # Create branch from Linear issue
mb commit "feat: add feature"  # Commit with proper formatting
mb push                     # Push with Linear integration
mb pr create               # Create PR with Linear linking

docs.title: PRD Process
docs.text:
Our PRD process follows these steps:

  1. Problem Definition - Identify user problems and business needs
  2. Solution Design - Propose solutions and alternatives
  3. Requirements Gathering - Define detailed functional requirements
  4. Review & Approval - Stakeholder review and sign-off
  5. Implementation Planning - Break down into engineering tasks
  6. Tracking & Updates - Monitor progress and update as needed

docs.title: PRD Template
docs.text:
All PRDs should include:

  • Executive Summary - High-level overview
  • Problem Statement - What problem are we solving?
  • Goals & Success Metrics - How will we measure success?
  • User Stories - Who will use this and how?
  • Functional Requirements - What should the product do?
  • Non-Functional Requirements - Performance, security, etc.
  • Design Mockups - Visual representations
  • Technical Considerations - Architecture and implementation notes
  • Timeline - Development milestones
  • Risks & Mitigation - Potential issues and solutions

docs.text:

  2. Fill out all required sections
  3. Get stakeholder input and review
  4. Submit for approval
  5. Add to this index once approved
